article.title: The MOSDEF Survey: Direct Observational Constraints on the Ionizing Photon Production Efficiency, $ξ_{\rm ion}$, at z 2

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary difference between the two ξion distributions shown in the top panel of Figure 1 (violet and green)?
choices: The green histogram represents galaxies at higher redshift than the violet histogram.
The green histogram assumes a Salpeter IMF, while the violet histogram assumes a Chabrier IMF.
The green histogram assumes a different UV dust attenuation curve compared to the violet histogram.
The green histogram includes the effects of binary star evolution, while the violet histogram does not.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which stellar population parameter, when varied in the BPASSv2 model (as shown in the bottom panel of Figure 1), results in the largest change in ξion?
choices: Upper Mass Cutoff of the IMF

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main point illustrated by the simulation shown in Figure 2?
choices: Dust attenuation has a negligible effect on the scatter of the ξion distribution.
Galaxy-to-galaxy variations in the dust attenuation curve can introduce a significant uncertainty in the measured scatter of ξion.
A single attenuation curve (e.g., Calzetti) is sufficient to accurately correct for dust attenuation in all galaxies.
The intrinsic scatter of the ξion distribution is much larger than the observed scatter.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend is observed in the top panel of Figure 3 regarding the relationship between ξion and the UV continuum slope (β)?
choices: ξion remains constant across all values of β.
ξion is elevated in galaxies with redder (less negative) β values.
ξion shows a positive correlation with β, increasing as β becomes bluer (more negative).
ξion is elevated in galaxies with bluer (more negative) β values.
